channel.title: Science
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Broken Teeth And Fake-umentaries: Another Shark Week Gone By
item.description: Alastair Bland looks at the dangers to real sharks and the hazards of pseudo-documentaries as another Shark Week draws to a close.
item.content:encoded:
Alastair Bland looks at the dangers to real sharks and the hazards of pseudo-documentaries as another Shark Week draws to a close.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Alastair Bland

item.title: How Does Winning Math's Fields Medal Affect Productivity?
item.description: An analysis by two economists finds that winners of the medal, the most significant prize in mathematics, become significantly less productive in their chosen field of study after they win the prize.
item.content:encoded:
An analysis by two economists finds that winners of the medal, the most significant prize in mathematics, become significantly less productive in their chosen field of study after they win the prize.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Shankar Vedantam

item.title: New Cameras Will Map Florida's Reefs
item.description: A scientific survey of coral reefs off the Florida keys is being done using the same fish-eye camera lenses that Google uses to capture street views. Scientists will use the images for research.
item.content:encoded:
A scientific survey of coral reefs off the Florida keys is being done using the same fish-eye camera lenses that Google uses to capture street views. Scientists will use the images for research.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Cold Winter Depleted Some Coastal Fish Populations
item.description: The extreme cold weather on the East Coast last winter has meant that some fishermen have smaller catches this summer. NPR's Linda Wertheimer talks to fishing forecaster Mitchell Roffer in Florida.
item.content:encoded:
The extreme cold weather on the East Coast last winter has meant that some fishermen have smaller catches this summer. NPR's Linda Wertheimer talks to fishing forecaster Mitchell Roffer in Florida.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Fighting (Tasty) Invasive Fish With Forks And Knives
item.description: Invasive fish like snakeheads and Asian carp are threatening to wipe out aquatic ecosystems across the U.S. So chefs and environmental agencies are encouraging their communities to eat them up.
item.content:encoded:
Invasive fish like snakeheads and Asian carp are threatening to wipe out aquatic ecosystems across the U.S. So chefs and environmental agencies are encouraging their communities to eat them up.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Bonny Wolf

item.title: The Machine That Tried To Scan The Brain â€” In 1882
item.description: The inspiration for modern MRI brain scanners was built before World War I began, the Titanic sank, and humans took flight. Now neuroscientists are trying to give its inventor his due credit.
item.content:encoded:
The inspiration for modern MRI brain scanners was built before World War I began, the Titanic sank, and humans took flight. Now neuroscientists are trying to give its inventor his due credit.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Chris Benderev

item.title: For City Dwellers, Stargazing Can Make For A Stellar Vacation
item.description: For those willing to travel a bit, venture out and allow your eyes to adjust to the darkness, many places still offer the chance to enjoy the soul-lifting sight of a starry night sky.
item.content:encoded:
For those willing to travel a bit, venture out and allow your eyes to adjust to the darkness, many places still offer the chance to enjoy the soul-lifting sight of a starry night sky.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Laura Secorun Palet

item.title: Making Scripts And Science Match
item.description: How can screenwriters make sure the science and medical details of their shows are true to life? NPR's Scott Simon talks with Kate Langrall Folb of Hollywood, Health & Society, who helps them out.
item.content:encoded:
How can screenwriters make sure the science and medical details of their shows are true to life? NPR's Scott Simon talks with Kate Langrall Folb of Hollywood, Health & Society, who helps them out.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Scientists Test The World's Seas On Ocean Sampling Day
item.description: For one day this summer, scientists from around the globe decided to find out what's in our oceans' water. We go to the coast of Savannah, Ga., to find out what exactly they were looking for.
item.content:encoded:
For one day this summer, scientists from around the globe decided to find out what's in our oceans' water. We go to the coast of Savannah, Ga., to find out what exactly they were looking for.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Sarah McCammon

item.title: Startups Pitch Cricket Flour As The Best Protein You Could Eat
item.description: Cricket flour is a thing, and it's showing up in protein bars and baked goods. A few companies are testing the water to see if Americans can get on board with cricket as an alternative to meat or soy.
item.content:encoded:
Cricket flour is a thing, and it's showing up in protein bars and baked goods. A few companies are testing the water to see if Americans can get on board with cricket as an alternative to meat or soy.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Alexander McCall

item.title: Has Health Law Helped Young People Get Mental Health Treatment? Maybe
item.description: The Affordable Care Act has allowed many young adults to stay on their parents' insurance. A study suggests the coverage may be helping more of them get treatment for mental health issues.
item.content:encoded:
The Affordable Care Act has allowed many young adults to stay on their parents' insurance. A study suggests the coverage may be helping more of them get treatment for mental health issues.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Maanvi Singh

item.title: When Snails Lose Their Way
item.description: There are happy snails. There are lonely snails. And there are lost snails. This one is lost. Totally. But it sings.
item.content:encoded:
There are happy snails. There are lonely snails. And there are lost snails. This one is lost. Totally. But it sings.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Robert Krulwich

item.title: A Virtual Outbreak Offers Hints Of Ebola's Future
item.description: As the Ebola outbreak rages in West Africa, it is also unfolding â€” in a virtual sense â€” inside the computers of scientists trying to predict how far the outbreak will spread and when it will end.
item.content:encoded:
As the Ebola outbreak rages in West Africa, it is also unfolding â€” in a virtual sense â€” inside the computers of scientists trying to predict how far the outbreak will spread and when it will end.

item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: How A Dissolvable 'Tampon' Could One Day Help Women Stop HIV
item.description: Engineers have come up with an experimental technology that could make HIV prevention as easy as using a tampon. It's based on an ultrafine fabric that's thinner than a human hair.
item.content:encoded:
Engineers have come up with an experimental technology that could make HIV prevention as easy as using a tampon. It's based on an ultrafine fabric that's thinner than a human hair.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Diane Cole

item.title: A Scientist's Mission To Break The Itch-Scratch Cycle
item.description: Dr. Gil Yosipovitch is a leading scientist in the field of itch. He says he hopes to gain more respect for the debilitating power of chronic itch â€” and to get more doctors on the search for a cure.
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Gil Yosipovitch is a leading scientist in the field of itch. He says he hopes to gain more respect for the debilitating power of chronic itch â€” and to get more doctors on the search for a cure.
